dsTidyverseClient 0.1.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Using tidyverse within DataSHIELD

    Using tidyverse within DataSHIELD

    dstidyverse.Rmd
    library(dsTidyverseClient)

    Overview

    dsTidyVerseClient is the DataSHIELD implementation of selected functions from the Tidyverse. Most of these functions are from dplyr, with some planned implementations for functions from purrr and tidyr.

    As long as not potentially disclosing, all functionality from the original Tidyverse functions has been preserved. The main argument which is normally passed to the ... parameter in Tidyverse functions is passed as a list to the parameter tidy_select. Other arguments are passed to the relevant parameters which retain the same names as the original function.

    To illustrate the useage of these functions, we use DSLite which creates a virtual DataSHIELD session.

    Install and load packages 

    ## install.packages("dplyr")
## install.packages("DSLite")
## install.packages(c("dsBase", "dsBaseClient"), repos = "https://cran.obiba.org/")
## devtools::install_github("molgenis/dsTidyverse")
## devtools::install_github("molgenis/dsTidyverseClient")
require(DSLite)
require(dplyr)
require(dsBase)
require(dsBaseClient)
require(dsTidyverse)
require(dsTidyverseClient)

    Set up DSLite environement and log in. 

    data("mtcars")
dslite.server <- newDSLiteServer(tables=list(mtcars=mtcars))
data("logindata.dslite.cnsim")
logindata.dslite.cnsim <- logindata.dslite.cnsim %>%
  mutate(table = "mtcars")
dslite.server$config(defaultDSConfiguration(include=c("dsBase", "dsTidyverse")))
dslite.server$assignMethod("selectDS", "selectDS")
dslite.server$assignMethod("renameDS", "renameDS")
conns <- datashield.login(logindata.dslite.cnsim[1, ], assign=TRUE)

    Functions

    Select

    ds.select, implements all the flexibility of dplyr::select in subsetting columns. This includes: (i) the ability to pass unquoted column names which are evaluated as columns of df.name, and (ii) the ability to use tidyselect helper functions, such as contains. Below are some examples, for full details see the documentation for dplyr::select.

    Subset columns by name 

    ds.colnames("mtcars")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "mpg"  "cyl"  "disp" "hp"   "drat" "wt"   "qsec" "vs"   "am"   "gear" "carb"
    ds.select(df.name = "mtcars", tidy_select = list(mpg, disp, wt), newobj = "new_df")
ds.colnames("new_df")
#> $sim1
#> [1] "mpg"  "disp" "wt"

    Specify columns to exclude 

    ds.colnames("mtcars")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "mpg"  "cyl"  "disp" "hp"   "drat" "wt"   "qsec" "vs"   "am"   "gear" "carb"
    ds.select(df.name = "mtcars", tidy_select = list(!mpg), newobj = "new_df")
ds.colnames("new_df")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "cyl"  "disp" "hp"   "drat" "wt"   "qsec" "vs"   "am"   "gear" "carb"

    Specify a range of columns to keep 

    ds.colnames("mtcars")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "mpg"  "cyl"  "disp" "hp"   "drat" "wt"   "qsec" "vs"   "am"   "gear" "carb"
    ds.select(df.name = "mtcars", tidy_select = list(mpg:drat), newobj = "new_df")
ds.colnames("new_df")
#> $sim1
#> [1] "mpg"  "cyl"  "disp" "hp"   "drat"

    Specify column names using a regular expression 

    ds.colnames("mtcars")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "mpg"  "cyl"  "disp" "hp"   "drat" "wt"   "qsec" "vs"   "am"   "gear" "carb"
    ds.select(df.name = "mtcars", tidy_select = list(matches('[aeiou]')), newobj = "new_df")
ds.colnames("new_df")
#> $sim1
#> [1] "disp" "drat" "qsec" "am"   "gear" "carb"

    Combine multiple conditions with ‘&’ 

    ds.colnames("mtcars")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "mpg"  "cyl"  "disp" "hp"   "drat" "wt"   "qsec" "vs"   "am"   "gear" "carb"
    ds.select(df.name = "mtcars", tidy_select = list(starts_with('c') & ends_with('b')), newobj = "new_df")
ds.colnames("new_df")
#> $sim1
#> [1] "carb"

    Combine multiple conditions with ‘|’ 

    ds.colnames("mtcars")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "mpg"  "cyl"  "disp" "hp"   "drat" "wt"   "qsec" "vs"   "am"   "gear" "carb"
    ds.select(df.name = "mtcars", tidy_select = list(starts_with('c') | ends_with('b')), newobj = "new_df")
ds.colnames("new_df")
#> $sim1
#> [1] "cyl"  "carb"

    Rename

    ds.rename renames columns within a serverside dataframe. Column names are passed unquoted and are evaluated as column names within df.name. Below are some examples, see dplyr::rename for full details.

    ds.colnames("mtcars")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "mpg"  "cyl"  "disp" "hp"   "drat" "wt"   "qsec" "vs"   "am"   "gear" "carb"
    ds.rename(df.name = "mtcars", tidy_select = list(effiency = mpg, power = hp), newobj = "new_df")
#> Error in str_sub(str_replace_all(string, pattern = fixed("list("), replacement = ""), : could not find function "str_sub"
    ds.colnames("new_df")
#> $sim1
#> [1] "cyl"  "carb"

    Mutate

    ds.mutate creates new columns in a serverside dataframe. These new columns are normally transformations of existing columns. This reduces the number of steps currently required in DataSHIELD, i.e. creating a new vector and joining it back to an existing data frame. Again, column names are passed unquoted. Below are some examples, see dplyr::mutate for full details.

    Create columns which are transformations of existing variables: 

    ds.colnames("mtcars")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "mpg"  "cyl"  "disp" "hp"   "drat" "wt"   "qsec" "vs"   "am"   "gear" "carb"
    ds.mutate(
  df.name = "mtcars",
  tidy_select = list(mpg_trans = cyl*1000, new_var = (hp-drat)/qsec),
  newobj = "new_df")
ds.colnames("new_df")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "mpg"       "cyl"       "disp"      "hp"        "drat"      "wt"        "qsec"      "vs"       
#>  [9] "am"        "gear"      "carb"      "mpg_trans" "new_var"
    ds.mean("mtcars$cyl")
#> $Mean.by.Study
#>      EstimatedMean Nmissing Nvalid Ntotal
#> sim1        6.1875        0     32     32
#> 
#> $Nstudies
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $ValidityMessage
#>      ValidityMessage 
#> sim1 "VALID ANALYSIS"
    ds.mean("new_df$mpg_trans")
#> $Mean.by.Study
#>      EstimatedMean Nmissing Nvalid Ntotal
#> sim1        6187.5        0     32     32
#> 
#> $Nstudies
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $ValidityMessage
#>      ValidityMessage 
#> sim1 "VALID ANALYSIS"
    ds.mean("mtcars$hp")
#> $Mean.by.Study
#>      EstimatedMean Nmissing Nvalid Ntotal
#> sim1      146.6875        0     32     32
#> 
#> $Nstudies
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $ValidityMessage
#>      ValidityMessage 
#> sim1 "VALID ANALYSIS"
    ds.mean("mtcars$drat")
#> $Mean.by.Study
#>      EstimatedMean Nmissing Nvalid Ntotal
#> sim1      3.596563        0     32     32
#> 
#> $Nstudies
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $ValidityMessage
#>      ValidityMessage 
#> sim1 "VALID ANALYSIS"
    ds.mean("mtcars$qsec")
#> $Mean.by.Study
#>      EstimatedMean Nmissing Nvalid Ntotal
#> sim1      17.84875        0     32     32
#> 
#> $Nstudies
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $ValidityMessage
#>      ValidityMessage 
#> sim1 "VALID ANALYSIS"
    ds.mean("new_df$new_var")
#> $Mean.by.Study
#>      EstimatedMean Nmissing Nvalid Ntotal
#> sim1      8.372669        0     32     32
#> 
#> $Nstudies
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $ValidityMessage
#>      ValidityMessage 
#> sim1 "VALID ANALYSIS"

    Choose where the new columns are positioned in the dataframe with .before and .after: 

    ds.colnames("mtcars")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "mpg"  "cyl"  "disp" "hp"   "drat" "wt"   "qsec" "vs"   "am"   "gear" "carb"
    ds.mutate(
  df.name = "mtcars",
  tidy_select = list(mpg_trans = cyl*1000, new_var = (hp-drat)/qsec),
  newobj = "new_df",
  .before = "disp")
ds.colnames("new_df")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "mpg"       "cyl"       "mpg_trans" "new_var"   "disp"      "hp"        "drat"      "wt"       
#>  [9] "qsec"      "vs"        "am"        "gear"      "carb"

    Only keep the newly created variables with .keep: 

    ds.colnames("mtcars")
#> $sim1
#>  [1] "mpg"  "cyl"  "disp" "hp"   "drat" "wt"   "qsec" "vs"   "am"   "gear" "carb"
    ds.mutate(
  df.name = "mtcars",
  tidy_select = list(mpg_trans = cyl*1000, new_var = (hp-drat)/qsec),
  newobj = "new_df",
  .keep = "none")
ds.colnames("new_df")
#> $sim1
#> [1] "mpg_trans" "new_var"
